docs.abstract: Myanmar and Bangladesh are again taking up talks to repatriate the Rohingya. But conflicting goals, and wariness among the refugees, remain a roadblock.
docs.snippet: Myanmar and Bangladesh are again taking up talks to repatriate the Rohingya. But conflicting goals, and wariness among the refugees, remain a roadblock.
docs.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A senior cabinet minister and army general from Myanmar arrived in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Thursday to discuss a trouble-plagued scheme to repatriate Rohingya Muslims who fled military assaults and now are in camps in Bangladesh.

headline.main: Will the Rohingya Ever Return Home?
headline.print_headline: Hopes Are Dim for Talks to Repatriate Rohingya in Bangladesh

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

docs.abstract: More than half a million Rohingya refugees face looming disaster from floods and landslides when the first storms of the monsoon season hit their camp in Bangladesh.
docs.snippet: More than half a million Rohingya refugees face looming disaster from floods and landslides when the first storms of the monsoon season hit their camp in Bangladesh.
docs.lead_paragraph: The world’s largest refugee camp, a temporary home to more than half a million people that sprawls precariously across barren hills in southeastern Bangladesh, faces a looming disaster as early as April when the first storms of the monsoon season hit, aid workers warn.

headline.main: The Biggest Refugee Camp Braces for Rain: ‘This Is Going to Be a Catastrophe’
headline.print_headline: The Biggest Refugee Camp Braces for Rain:  ‘This Is Going to Be a Catastrophe’

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: United Nations High Commission for Refugees

byline.original: By Somini Sengupta and Henry Fountain

docs.abstract: More than 100,000 refugees live in Bangladeshi camps prone to high water and landslides. “Their lives are greatly at risk,” a top U.N. official said.
docs.snippet: More than 100,000 refugees live in Bangladeshi camps prone to high water and landslides. “Their lives are greatly at risk,” a top U.N. official said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Rohingya refugees who have fled ethnic violence in Myanmar are at risk of “a humanitarian crisis within the crisis” as the impending cyclone and monsoon seasons threaten to flood camps and fuel the spread of disease, diplomats at the United Nations Security Council warned on Tuesday.

headline.main: Besieged Rohingya Face ‘Crisis Within the Crisis’: Deadly Floods
headline.print_headline: As Rain Clouds Gather, Double Crisis Brews for Displaced Rohingya

docs.abstract: The race to rebuild the world’s largest refugee camp, where monsoon rains threaten flooding, landslides and disease.
docs.snippet: The race to rebuild the world’s largest refugee camp, where monsoon rains threaten flooding, landslides and disease.
docs.lead_paragraph: The race to rebuild the world’s largest refugee camp, where monsoon rains threaten flooding, landslides and disease.

docs.abstract: What is being done to protect Rohingya refugees from flooding, landslides and disease?
docs.snippet: What is being done to protect Rohingya refugees from flooding, landslides and disease?
docs.lead_paragraph: This feature will return on Sept. 4. For now, take a look at what else we’re offering for the 2018-19 school year.

docs.abstract: Dozens of people were also injured after an elephant tore through the camp in Bangladesh, home to hundreds of thousands of Rohingya.
docs.snippet: Dozens of people were also injured after an elephant tore through the camp in Bangladesh, home to hundreds of thousands of Rohingya.
docs.lead_paragraph: One child was killed and dozens of people were injured on Thursday when an elephant tore through a refugee camp in Bangladesh, home to hundreds of thousands of Rohingya who have fled the conflict in Myanmar.

headline.main: Elephant Tramples a Refugee Camp, and a Child is Killed

docs.abstract: More records for both wet and dry weather are being set around the globe, according to a study published Wednesday.
docs.snippet: More records for both wet and dry weather are being set around the globe, according to a study published Wednesday.
docs.lead_paragraph: More records for both wet and dry weather are being set around the globe, often with disastrous consequences for the people facing such extremes, according to a study published Wednesday that offered new evidence of climate change’s impacts in the here and now.

headline.main: More Floods and More Droughts: Climate Change Delivers Both
headline.print_headline: More Floods, More Droughts: Climate Change Delivers Both

keywords.value: Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (Journal)

docs.abstract: Myanmar’s government signed an agreement with the United Nations, but few expect the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic minority forced to flee Myanmar, to go home anytime soon.
docs.snippet: Myanmar’s government signed an agreement with the United Nations, but few expect the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic minority forced to flee Myanmar, to go home anytime soon.
docs.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s government on Thursday announced that it had reached an agreement with the United Nations that would be a first step toward the possible return of Rohingya Muslims to the country.

headline.main: Myanmar and U.N. Agree to Aim for Repatriation of Rohingya
headline.print_headline: U.N. Reaches Initial Deal On Rohingya

docs.abstract: The stakes are high, the secretary general said, but he suggested that United States plans to quit the Paris Agreement didn’t matter much.
docs.snippet: The stakes are high, the secretary general said, but he suggested that United States plans to quit the Paris Agreement didn’t matter much.
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Nuclear weapons? Famine? Civil war? Nope.

headline.main: Biggest Threat to Humanity? Climate Change, U.N. Chief Says

keywords.value: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

docs.abstract: You doubt climate change? Come to this island — but hurry, before it disappears.
docs.snippet: You doubt climate change? Come to this island — but hurry, before it disappears.
docs.lead_paragraph: KUTUBDIA, Bangladesh — Anyone who doubts climate change should come to this lovely low-lying island, lapped by gentle waves and home to about 100,000 people.

headline.print_headline: Come to This Island, Before It Disappears
